study_identification.title: Brain-Charting Autism and Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Reveals Distinct and Overlapping Neurobiology

study_characteristics.study_objective: Use population (normative) modeling with a large multisite T1 MRI dataset to characterize cortical anatomy in autism and ADHD versus typical development, examining sex and age effects and the co-occurring autism+ADHD subgroup.

clinical_application_and_analysis.association_analysis: Multiple linear regressions on centile scores with covariates (age, Euler number); FDR correction for multiple comparisons; spin permutation tests for spatial correlations of effect maps; additional analyses include sex-stratified effects, age-by-diagnosis interactions, and correlations/overlap in regions with extreme deviations.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_brief: Autism and ADHD show distinct cortical patterns: autism with localized increases (notably superior temporal), ADHD with more global CT increases but lower volume and surface area; co-occurring autism+ADHD shows a unique mixed profile; sex modulates autism effects but not ADHD; ADHD shows age-by-diagnosis effects.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_detailed: Robust neuroanatomical signatures were observed for both conditions. Autistic individuals showed greater cortical thickness and volume localized to superior temporal cortex, whereas ADHD showed more global increases in cortical thickness but lower cortical volume and surface area across much of the cortex. The co-occurring autism+ADHD group showed widespread increases in cortical thickness with some decreases in surface area. Sex modulated autism neuroanatomy (sex-specific profiles differ) but not ADHD; an age-by-diagnosis interaction was present for ADHD. Effect sizes were generally small, and sensitivity analyses (global measure control; QC variants) indicated stability of main findings.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_limitations: Residual site heterogeneity cannot be fully eliminated; centiles generated out-of-sample despite overlap with original BrainCharts to account for site differences; hemispheric averaging due to model availability may mask asymmetry; limited and inconsistent phenotypic/diagnostic data (no IQ modeling); sample representativeness issues (sex imbalance, fewer lower-IQ/high-support participants, limited racial-ethnic diversity); lack of longitudinal data.
clinical_application_and_analysis.application_notes: Two-step harmonization and modeling: ComBat by site with covariates (age, sex, diagnosis) followed by out-of-sample BrainCharts GAMLSS centiles; rigorous QC with FSQC thresholding and Euler covariate; spin tests for spatial map comparisons; sensitivity analyses controlling for global measures and varying QC thresholds.

general_notes.general_notes: Subcortical/cerebellar normative models were not available at analysis time; hemispheric averages were used since BrainCharts hemisphere-specific models were unavailable. The supplement compares out-of-sample centiles (site-resolved) to original in-sample centiles for ABIDE, showing high correlations (GMV r=0.88; WMV r=0.91; sGMV r=0.93; ventricular volume r=0.97).
